turns.content: Gluten-free ice cream is intended for individuals with celiac disease or a gluten intolerance, as gluten can cause an immune response in these individuals that can lead to damage to the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, and can be found in many processed foods, including ice cream. Gluten-free ice cream is made using ingredients that do not contain gluten, such as cornstarch or rice flour, in place of wheat-based ingredients. Some people without gluten intolerance also choose gluten-free ice cream as a healthier or lower-calorie option.
what is the selling point selling ice cream in new zealand?

There are several selling points for ice cream in New Zealand.

* The natural ingredients: New Zealand is known for its high-quality dairy products, and using local and natural ingredients in your ice cream can be a selling point for customers who are looking for fresh and authentic flavors.
* Unique and creative flavors: Offering unique and creative flavors can help set your ice cream apart from others and appeal to customers who are looking for something new and exciting.
* Gluten-free and other dietary options: As mentioned earlier, offering gluten-free and other dietary options can be a selling point for customers who have specific dietary needs or preferences.
* Local and sustainable production: Consumers are increasingly interested in supporting local and sustainable businesses, so highlighting the local and sustainable aspects of your ice cream production can be a selling point.
* Branding and packaging: Having a strong brand and packaging can be a selling point, especially in the competitive market. It can make your ice cream stand out and make it more attractive to customers.

Overall, the key selling point for ice cream in New Zealand would be the combination of high quality ingredients, unique and creative flavors and sustainable production, with a good branding and packaging.

There are a few key things to consider when starting an ice cream business in New Zealand:

1. Research: Conduct market research to understand the current ice cream market in New Zealand, including trends, competition, and consumer preferences.
2. Develop a business plan: Use your research to develop a comprehensive business plan that outlines your goals, target market, and financial projections.
3. Develop your product: Create a unique and delicious product that stands out from the competition, using high-quality and natural ingredients.
4. Register your business and obtain licenses and permits: Register your business and obtain any necessary licenses and permits to operate in New Zealand.
5. Choose a location: Choose a location for your ice cream business, whether it's a storefront, a food truck, or a stand at a market or festival.
6. Create a branding and packaging: Develop a strong brand and packaging for your ice cream that will make it stand out and attract customers.
7. Develop a marketing strategy: Create a marketing strategy to promote your ice cream business and attract customers. This can include social media, advertising, and public relations.
8. Test your product: Test your product with a small group of customers before launching your business to get feedback and make any necessary adjustments.
9. Prepare for the launch: Prepare for the launch of your business by ordering equipment, hiring staff, and stocking up on ingredients.

Remember, starting a business can be challenging, but with the right preparation, planning and execution, it can be a very rewarding experience.

Starting an ice cream shop business can be a rewarding experience, but it also comes with its own set of pros and cons. Here are some of the main pros and cons to consider:

Pros:

* High demand: Ice cream is a popular treat, and there is a high demand for it all year round.
* Seasonal income: Many ice cream shops see a spike in sales during the summer months, which can provide a boost in income during the busy season.
* Low startup costs: Starting an ice cream shop can be relatively inexpensive compared to other types of businesses.
* Flexibility: Running an ice cream shop can provide a good balance of independence and flexibility, as well as the possibility of working during the evening and weekends.
* Creative freedom: There are endless possibilities for flavor combinations and creative ice cream creations.

Cons:

* Weather dependent: Sales can be affected by the weather, and some days can be slow during the winter and rainy days.
* Seasonal labor: During the busy season, it can be difficult to find enough staff to work and manage the shop.
* High overhead costs: Running an ice cream shop can be expensive, with costs such as rent, utilities, and ingredients.
* Short shelf life: Ice cream has a short shelf life and must be sold quickly
